sectionTitle: Some Evidence on Acquisitions:Does M&A Pay?

columns.text:
## a.

The goal of this task is to explain what the evidence says about the benefits of mergers and acquisitions to target company shareholders.

In this section, we have a reference to several studies that have examined the gains and losses in stock value around the time of merger announcements. Based on this, is clear that ***the main benefit that target company shareholders experience is the immediate gain due to the premium typically paid by bidders***.

## b.

The goal of this task is to explain what the evidence says about the benefits of mergers and acquisitions to acquiring company shareholders

In this section, there are references to several studies that have examined the gains and losses in stock value around the time of merger announcements. Based on this, an explanation of the benefits of acquiring company shareholders after mergers and acquisitions explains that shareholders in bidder firms seem to neither win nor lose very much, at least on average.

The main reasons are: 
- If managers of bidding firms tend to overestimate the gains from acquisition, then shareholders will have losses instead of expected gains from the merger.

- Bidding firm is usually a larger firm so its percentage gains are much lower. 

- Management may not be acting in the interest of shareholders when it attempts to acquire other firms.

- The prices paid in acquisitions fully reflect the value of the acquired firms. In other words, the sellers capture all of the gains.

- The announce intentions to engage in ***merger programs*** long before that announce specific acquisitions makes that information to the market about the bidding firm is not updated, creating anticipated gains from mergers.
